trial_identification.studytitle: Morphine versus Ketamine for traumatic pain in the prehospital setting
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Reduction in pain Verbal Numeric Rating Scale (VNRS) using morphine compared to Ketamine for patients presenting with traumatic pain in the prehospital setting

interventions.interventions: Ketamine Hydrochloride (Intervention) 10-20 mgs bolus Intraveneously every three minutes. Patients will continue to receive boluses of the drug until either; 1. Patient is pain free 2. Side effects develop or 3. Arrival at a receiving Emergency Department
interventions.comparator: Morphine Sulphate (Control) 1 - 5 mgs bolus Intraveneously every five minutes. Patients will continue to receive boluses of the drug until either; 1. Patient is pain free 2. Side effects develop or 3. Arrival at a receiving Emergency Department

primaryOutcome.outcome: Change in pain Verbal Numeric Rating Scale (VNRS)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: On arrival at a receiving hospital Emergency Department

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Incidence of adverse events, such as excessive sedation, blood pressure changes, arrhythmias, nause and vomiting
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Until arrival at a receiving Emergency Department

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Total dose of opioid required for pain relief
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: On arrival at a receiving hospital Emergency Department

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Attended by participating ambulance crew Patient conscious (GCS=15), speaking and able to rate their pain using the Verbal Numerical Rating Scale (VNRS) Moderate to Severe pain due to trauma defined as VNRS of 5 or greater.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Known allergy to ketamine hydrochloride or morphine sulphate Pregnant or lactating women Ischameic chest pain, acute pulmonary oedema and/or severe hypertension (Systolic Blood Pressure>180 mmHg) Head injury with a history of loss of consciousness or Glasgow Coma Scale<15 Inability to obtain venous access Presumed intoxication with alcohol or illicit substances

trial_design.concealment: Patients will be allocated to receive intravenous morphine and ketamine or intravenous morphine alone. Randomisation will be decided by sealed opaque envelope block randomisation following inclusion into the trial.
trial_design.sequence: Participants will be allocated to one of the two study arms dependant upon opaque envelope block randomisation. Envelopes will be randomly shuffled and then sequentially numbered.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Monash University Commercial Road, Prahran, Melbourne

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Health Research Level 7 222 Exhibition Street Melbourne

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Rural Ambulance Victoria 23 Wetlands Drive Mount Helen VIC 3350

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The ambulance services are conducting a project to compare the pain killing qualities of two medications, ketamine and morphine in people with moderate to severe pain following a traumatic injury.
We are hoping to determine which medication is best to use when the ambulance services attend a person with an injury and are in pain.
